title: Can there be another alphabet letter? - Quora

response.answer_text: Yes. The current English alphabet added three letters to the 23-letter Latin alphabet (I became I and J; V became U and V; and W was created from VV). Other languages using the Latin alphabet use extra letters. German adds Ä, Ö, Ü and ß. Icelandic adds Ð, Þ and Æ. Spanish adds Ñ. English used to have more letters, but they fell out of use, the last to go being the long s (ſ), sometimes confused with f, but which was used for initial and medial s. Long s - Wikipedia It fell out of use in the 18th century. It would be most useful for those sounds that are currently written with two letters, e.g., ng, sh and th. However, alphabets are very conservative, so change is unlikely.

There’s no law against it. But we are incredibly locked in, today, to keyboards with a certain number of letters on them. And ASCII and other electronic alphabets which expect 26 letters. Sure, you can find a unicode slot free for a new letter. But it would be a massive amount of work to upgrade all our IT infrastructure to handle it. Waaaaay worse than the “millenium bug” or the end of Unix time. I can’t imagine a need that is compelling enough to convince us to do all that work. I think we’re stuck with a 26 letter alphabet for the next few thousand years. Update : Of course, we are adding new “characters” to our everyday electronic conversations all the time, in the form of Emojis. There is infrastructure to handle that. But people don’t consider them part of the alphabet. If you want to make your mark on our writing, you might be better off trying to invent a compelling new Emoji.

The following sounds exist in English, but do not have a separate letter: /ð/ = this or that /θ/ = thick or thin /ʃ/ = fish, profession /ʧ/ = chocolate, connection /ŋ/ = singing In principle, we could use a separate letter for all five of those. In particular, the first two. Arabic has two separate letters for “dhul” and “thaa.” In Greek, the letters are called “dhilta” and “theta” respectively. It makes little sense to use the same pair of letters (th) to represent both sounds. Of course, it is possible. Unfortunately, getting others to go along with your program will be an uphill road.

you know, letters have in the past been removed and added like with the inclusion of w, so upping the letter count would better be done by reintroducing removed letters that making up something new. even in the case of the inclusion of w it wasn’t really more making something up, it was more simplifying since it was made to replace a sound written down in text as uu/vv, that’s why it’s called “double u.” a list of letters in the Latin alphabet made back in 1011 included these letters; & ⁊ Ƿ Þ Ð Æ. that same list of letters used omitted some of the newer inclusions we have now such as w and j.

The Russian (Cyrillic) alphabet has 33 letters, including several that we spell with a stack of letters—tsch, sch, etc. Conceptually, it wouldn’t be too hard to incorporate any of these letters into the standard Latin alphabet. Good luck with that.
